I think the coinflip researchers were looking it backwards. More interesting question to me is whether you can build a machine that flips a coin so that you cannot predict its end state, or not. I get that they probably were trying to answer questions about randomness of a dice not whether or not the universe is deterministic. And when it comes to these two men going to the party, could we build a machine(even theoretically) that predicts are they going or not. And when the machine tell us that they are going, would we have enough confidence in the machine to go to these men and say "We predict that you are going to the party and are willing to bet all we are worth on that.". When self reference gets introduced in to a system, determinism flies out of the window. Determinism seems to me to be something that can be imposed(kind of like with those quantum entangled particles).This opens up lot of questions on how does the way we look at the world around us affects the way reality lays it self out, or does it? And role and nature of freewill. I am bit late to the party, but there is my 2 cents anyway.

How can one make a perfectly predictable system out of a smaller perfectly random system? If everything has this perfectly random system determined by quantum mechanics, then how are we able to predict things like if I let go of a ball, it will fall (as a basic example). Also, even though everyTHING should be perfectly random (on a small scale), not everything is a thing, like our number system, it is not exactly a thing an it therefor does not need to abide by these laws. 2 + 2 will always equal 4, and while that statement makes sense on every level (2+2=4) what determines that statement to be true in our reality. It could also be true that 2+2=5 in a another reality with completely different physics (this is a very complicated idea to understand). so my point is, everything that happens macroscopically can be defined by what happens at a microscopic scale, so, what defines the smallest set of true facts that build our universe, what if 2+2=5?

A philosophical question: does randomness even exist? Asked differently: are there (or can there even be) sources of randomness?

There are sources of unpredictability (like rolling dice), but whether our universe is deterministic or non-deterministic is unknown - whether it contains (or is linked to inside or outside) sources of randomness.

Let's roll two dice, your eyes will see the result and let's assume your result R0 is governed by randomness. But to determine the outcome of your dice, there must be "something/someone", unseen in the background, that "rolled his own dice" (R1), to determine the result of your dice in the first place! But to get randomness into R1, there must be a R2, which in turn needs a R3 to feed its randomness, then a R4 etc.

The whole concept of "source of randomness" becomes an infinite loop!

So from this point of view two scenarios appear on the surface: A) there is a "God of Randomness" / "God of Chaos" or B) randomness does not exist, our universe is 100% deterministic.

Gods throwing their "magical dice" (rock bottom randomness; results even unknown to them!) to determine outcomes, used where they don't want to decide the outcome themselves, sounds quite crazy.

Although, on closer inspection the concept of (source of) randomness is crazy in itself! Logic, mathematics or physics can't find, expose, create, generate or explain (sources of) randomness. Maths and computer programs can only create sequences of pseudo-random numbers. Then (as far as we know or believe) classical or quantum physics can only create unpredictability.

Randomness is a great mystery...

I find the ending very misleading, he spends the entire video pointing at how random is a blanket word we use for something we don't quite understand. Then he assumes, because of our lack of technology, that on a quantum level that all things are random RATHER than assuming that it appears random at the moment, but eventually we might come to a point of being able to predict and understand great unknowns (Quantum Mechanics in this case) like we've done with every field of science. And from there you can even mention how we would probably hit another wall and eventually you wonder if we'll truly understand the smallest possible unit of measurement. I just think if we are to assume something that probably will always be on the edge of science's understanding, aka whether the universe is random or pre determined, we should go with the option that is the most consistent with reality. What's more consistent an orderly universe created from pure randomness, or an orderly universe created from an infinitely deep function that will always appear random if you go deeper than you should but still functions orderly no matter how deep you understand. The concept of an eternally deep and complex reality seems bizarre, but randomness is beyond bizarre, the only thing I can think of more bizarre is non-existence.

My problem with the claim about the quantum properties only being determined when you measure them is that every experiment I have been able to find only proves that the entangled particles have the shared property. I've seen experiments that supposedly disprove this, but they all still boil down to something that can be determined at any measurement point. The one that comes closest is the one minutephysics goes over in the multiple polarized lens experiments, and I keep having to go back to them to try to really wrap my head around it, but in the end, the nature of the problem remains: how do you do an experiment that proves that the property is determined when it's measured, rather than that the property was established?

Even the uncertainty principle only makes statements about the impossibility of performing a measurement without disrupting the system to the point that you can't perform another measurement that has meaning. i.e., all testing is destructive, so even if you measure a property, you can't any longer know the property you just measured because you disrupted it in measuring it.

Further, it is typical, but ultimately foolish, for us to assume it is human observation that matters in determining a quantum state. The quanta add up to macrostates, and those macrostates are imminently predictable. Now, yes, they're predictable due to an overwhelming addition of myriad probabilities. That is, they're as predictable as saying that the average of all numbers rolled on a fair d6 will be 3.5 after a significantly large number of rolls.

But what that means is that something other than humans are measuring their values, and they are, in fact, aggregating their probabilities without ever being individually measured, but creating macrostates.

I know the pop sci interpretation - which quantum physicists often use, so I am not dismissing it based on it being popular science - is that this means they're ONLY probabilities, and the deterministic macrostate is just a sum of the underlying unobserved probabilities, but this isn't really supported by any of the basis for QM as I understand it. (This could mean I still lack understanding; QM isn't my field of physics.) QM, as I understand it, only gives us the fact that we can't KNOW it until we observe it, and that observing it changes it.

It does give us particles that can self-interfere as if they were waves, but that's a function of energy being quantized and the "particle" being just a wave that has its smallest possible amount of energy while still existing.

But these quantum states exist, and I have yet to see evidence that they truly are in a literal, physical superposition of all possible states until "observed." Because, again, what does "observation" mean? By who or what? There is no functional difference, perhaps, between it having a probability of having decayed or not that is determined only when the fact that it is or is not decayed matters, and it having actually decayed or not decayed by the time it matters. But by the same token, then, why insist on this strange, hard-to-understand idea that it's "determined when measured?"

It's certainly discovered only when measured. And if we treat it like that, a lot of QM makes more sense to the layperson. I'm really struggling to see how these experiments show that this is a false way of looking at it, and if I'm wrong, I'd like to grasp how and why.

But "what is observing?" is crucial. We discuss it with terms of detectors, but in practice, for a baseball to be hit by a bat, all those quantum states must add up to the sum that leads to Newton's Laws holding true. And you could say, "Well, you're observing all of them," but, no, you're not. You're observing a macrostate that is a sum of them. Nobody has measured that baseball's every quantum state. Nobody ever will; that baseball has already been hit and those states long-ago changed. But the process of "observation" by the fellow particles has occurred. At what point were they observed, however? All the other observers were also in superpositions. How do any of them observe each other, when they're not sure when they'll interact?

And again, how does the end result differ from if they all are in defined quantum states that are just too hard to measure to predict until they interact with each other in their definite states?

It's the randomness of a deck of cards compared to the randomness of a die in motion.

Can one understand, explain and predict a certain outcome of happening? As i stated before, you could actually measure "randomness", but to explain why something happens exactly the way it happens, would be more difficult, if not completely impossible. Independently of a outcome distribution type being more random or less random, it would not be expected that a human being could actually understand, explain and predict a certain outcome type or a certain sequence of happening. We as human beings are limited in our capabilities, intelligence, comprehension, etc. Possible outcome distribution types or sequences are influenced and conditioned by an almost infinite group of factors and variables. To fully understand why something behaves the way it does, one would have to simultaneously embrace and dominate all these variables. If a outcome type is truly random to it's fullest extent than we would have to admit that there are no variables or external factors that are influencing and restricting the outcomes. That is why true "randomness" is a theoretical concept, because in a real physical world/scenario it would be incomprehensive that a generation of outcomes wouldn't have any conditional or influential elements.

Can we measure "randomness"? If we consider the premise that true "randomness" exists to it's fullest extent when all the possible outcomes have EXACTLY the same probability of happening and acknowledge that "randomness" is a relative concept, then it is theoretically and mathematically possible to measure "randomness". The only way to achieve this is by conducting a massive amount of events/trials/experiments (the bigger the number the more precise are our conclusions). In order to measure "randomness", the specific outcome sequence would not be relevant by itself, since any sequence has the exact probability of happening (although this would be difficult for most people to understand ). The truth is that, only through the analysis of the distribution type of the outcome frequencies that a certain sequence belongs to, are we able to, effectively, measure "randomness".

i can give you people 2 concrete examples of pure randomness. OK:
1): The fact that you, who are reading this, is born in a certain area of the earth, in a certain moment in the flow of time is not parameterable nor has any reason to be so, it is just random.
2): Say you go outside tomorrow for a walk. While you are walking, it starts being awfully windy. The moment this happens, you happen to pass by a 2 storey house with a balcony. So a plant falls from the balcony on your head and you die.
Before you start complaining that the setting is too much, i will say that the randomness in this, is the facts you decided to get out for a walk and that you passed by a 2 storey house with a balcony that had some plants on it. Your choice to go for a walk had nothing to do with the outcome nor was it the reason of it. Now if you want to call a choice passing below a 2 storey house with a balcony on a windy day be my guest, but probably you wouldn't even notice in that situation. The reason was the windy day, that would have happened even if you didn't go out for a walk that day.
As to why it is random for a day to become windy, you sure go out of your house every day right? Is it always windy? No, this is actually decided by the rotation of the earth and some stuff i don't probably know, but the combination of a random person's choices and the current weather conditions in his town arriving at a specific outcome is random in my opinion.

Short answer: Random doesn't exist. Everything is consequential and have reason.

Random - is what we call something, like a result, that we aren't going to calculate. Whether it's because we don't have the means to do it or any other reason. Nothing is random. We call things random for the same reason we say 'I don't know'. Random is something you don't know how to predict. Even when flipping a coin, the result could be calculated through environmental knowledge, forces and bodies that interreact. Like how much force you put in what specific muscle of your hand. How much your finger accelerates vs friction force. Gravity. Angle of, well, everything. Do you move your hand in any way after you catapult the coin, which can influence the number of flips in mid air. Does the angle at which it lands on your hand is enough to stop, or will it friction through for an extra final flip to the other side. So, so many factors, that are objectively absolutely calculatable, but we just don't do it. Nothing is ever random. Not chaos, not entropy, nothing.

random is relative.  the less ignorant someone is the less things would seem to be random because they would have more knowledge of what to expect. So is something random or are you just "dumb" and cant "think outside the box"?

made, done, happening, or chosen without method or conscious decision (google search definition) random where i'm from is used in place of unexpected. without consious decision is basically saying in ignorance/ unexpected. random is a relative term. could be slightly to completely. uncertain (having some knowledge of the parameters but still not sure of the outcome) to completely unexpected (having no prior conscious reasoning of what was to come). seemingly no logical method or pattern. everything is random to an extent, however shouldnt be considered random unless there was very low chance in the outcome, flipping a coin heads or tails or on the edge shouldn't be considered random its 1 of 3 outcomes. how unlikely does it need to be for it to feel like it deserves to be considered random? 0 percent uncertain/certain to 100 percent uncertain/completely unexpected? 90 percent uncertain is like pick a whole number between 0 and 11 (1,2,3,4,5,6,7,8,9 or 10) 10 options without any further knowledge like knowing the biases of the person what numbers they don't like what numbers they do and so forth like me i would almost always pick 7 is my favorite number but without knowing that it would seem to be 1 out of 10 chance to think or expect what would be the outcome. to be random i think it needs to be more then just one angle not just the uncertainty but the lack of being able to determine what the outcome could be like pick a whole number between 0 and 11 and the outcome is chosen to be waffle that could be considered random but having a computer "randomly pick a password" 8 to 16 characters long u know the parameters there is a lot of options but it is still expected to be something. if the outcome was more then 16 characters it could be random or if it used characters not part of the options something you wouldn't expect. basically i think random should mean;    random = no pattern + unexpected + unlikely. the less ignorant someone is the less things would be random to them. so is something random or are you just too ignorant and cant "think outside the box"? if you could calculate the chance of something u would have prior knowledge to the possible outcomes and it wouldn't be expected to begin with also if you saw a pattern it wouldn't be expected so really random is simply something unexpected so if u filled ur mind with enough information enough possibilities eventually nothing would be random because u would have seen it before you could have the idea of it happening again. pick a number between 0 and 11 person chooses the answer to be waffle not random u heard that outcome before it wasn't unexpected whats the point of the word random if it literally means unexpected? unanticipated if someone is completely ignorant everything is random if someone is all knowing nothing is random. you don't have to be able to guarantee something will happen for it to not be random technically you cant guarantee anything but things can be unexpected until it is expected while it is unexpected its random when its no longer unexpected its no longer random.

Except of course random variables do exhibit patterns at the population level. If they didn't we would not have statistics. It is hard to predict when an individual will die, but plot the distribution of the age people die and it has found to follow a Gaussian distribution. A fair dice would have a flat distribution. Other random variables may follow a Poissonian distribution. Or a Weibull distribution.

Brownian motion is "random". But I guess that shows there is a difference between something that is fundamentally non-deterministic and vs something that is practically indeterminate. Random describes the summation of very large number of tiny sources of variation which we cannot hope to model, so we model the population via statistics.

Assuming the universe is superimposed, as the many worlds hypothesis states (which, as far as I'm aware, is a well accepted interpretation of quantum mechanics) you can predict any physically possible outcome of a random event (because they all happen) but, since you only find yourself in one of the infinite branching universes, your prediction is meaningless. This is because, in the combined branching universes, where you have made a prediction, you will be wrong and you will be right, with a statistical distribution which is the same as a random probability distribution; the same as randomness, basically.

From "A Theory of Pure Film": In retrospect it occurred to me that the above process could be seen as exemplifying what could be called a “law of small numbers,” by analogy with “the law of large numbers” so important to probability theory. What’s implied in the above study is the notion that what we usually think of as “random” is not mathematical at base, but fundamentally perceptual. This is illustrated by the various sets of short black-white runs considered above, some of which seem more “random” than others, despite the fact that so few elements are involved that the law of large numbers which defines randomness mathematically doesn’t apply. In other words, it would seem that, at base, our notion of randomness is fundamentally intuitive rather than strictly mathematical. Another way of looking at it is to consider a run of, say, 2,3,6,2,3,6,2,3,6, 2,3,6. Though this does not look random, strictly speaking it could have been produced through some “random” process, such as tossing a die 12 times. So while there is no way to determine whether any set of outcomes could have been produced by a random method when only a small number of events is involved, it is possible to characterize such a small run as either “random” or not through purely intuitive methods. https://antacticstructures.blogspot.com/2018/12/a-theory-of-pure-film-part-ii-only.html

Sorry, but he is simply wrong about determinism here. Atmospheric noise is not deterministic in any ultimate sense. Even with absolute knowledge of every particle, spin, position, velocity, and knowing all the different sources of radiation interacting with the atmosphere, and knowing all the sources of noise we produce, and those produced by other sources in nature, we could not create a deterministic model for the noise in the atmosphere. It is truly noise. It is affected by quantum vacuum fluctuations and Brownian motion both of which are truly and absolutely random in every sense of that word. Anything made of atoms or even sub particles is going to have velocities and positions that cannot be truly deterministic. The universe itself prohibits absolute determinism which is why we have a limitation on the meaning of length and time, something we call Planck length and Planck time. Below those limits, our ability to meaningfully measure either quantity is impossible due to the inherent fluctuations of the quantum realm.

For example, you cannot with any precision at all, predict where an electron will be in it's shell around an atomic nucleus. It is simply impossible to ascertain, no matter how good your technology. The best anyone could do is define the electron by its probabilistic set of positions, which tells us the shape of the electron shell. In fact, there is no point at which it is valid to say the electron IS at any one position, even if we admit we cannot know that position. An electron doesn't occupy a single position in space in that sense.

Similarly, any pattern we detect in flipping coins is only a buffering effect of true randomness. Radiation sources affect the spin and flipping in subtle but real ways such that over time, your determinism will be violated RANDOMLY. The trick is to make the buffering effect strong enough to overcome the subtle fluctuations of space time. In the case of coins, if you make a precision-flipper machine, you effectively cancel out any possibility of an quantum fluctuation affecting that macroscopic device and process. But radio noise, or atmospheric noise, are completely randomized because they are caused by interactions at the particle level.

The point of a radio amplifier in signal transmission is to buffer against that noise so profoundly that a clear pattern can be established above the noise floor, which can then be ignored. But even that pattern will have subtle fluctuations embedded inside that pattern that are truly random because that noise floor still exists. If you were transmitting a series of notes of music, you have no guarantee that any particular note will be received at exactly 13.0 decibel microvolts per meter by the receiver, even if the transmitter is adjusted manually and carefully to achieve that reading in a constant way. Even if the transmitter and receiver were but a foot apart, and the guy tuning the transmitter could see the readout on the receiver, he could never get a desired reception measurement. There will always be some decimal point difference in the desired deterministic reception strength and the actual reception strength because one is dealing with moving electromagnetic waves in space-time, which must interact with the fluctuating fabric thereof in truly random ways. The universe causes truly random noise that can affect all processes.

Finally, a nice macroscopic size example of randomness is the height of any ship on the sea with respect to sea level. The waves on the ocean are not truly deterministic because they are affected by subtle changes in air movement, planetary movement, rotational speed variations, the Moon's changing position, the fluctuating radiation level of the Sun, and even cosmic rays. The last two in particular are truly random sources, much like static. As water absorbs or releases heat, it changes in density and volume, thus changing the size of wave undulating on it's surface in random ways. You might see a 20 foot wave, but even if you measured it precisely at a given time, you could always zoom in closer and closer to the edge of that wave to discover there IS NO EDGE and thus no definite boundary in space-time between the top of the wave and the air above. In addition, the spacing between the molecules of water and other compounds will randomly fluctuate such that even if there WERE an absolute top of the wave at the molecular level, the fluctuating spacing between the molecules beneath that top will cause the height to change in a truly random way nobody, even with absolute knowledge, could predict.

Absolute determinism is a dead concept.

FYI… Bell’s Inequalities can be reproduced by Macroscopic Real Objects, using classical wave functions.


All one has to do is have a large pool, self-propelled model boats that do not have a steering system and a series of short parallel walls that can vibrate and produce waves.


First one has to create the parallel walls that are just wide enough so that if a boat is sent on a parallel direction to the canals created that they can reasonably pass through without the boats touching the wall (which would be a fail). Then send the boats on slightly canted angles and using classical wave mechanics most should fail the test.


Now vibrate those walls in which pressure from the waves creates a low-pressure zone in the center of those walls​ so that the boats will head that direction in a path that is parallel to the walls. The boats should then be able to Violate Bell’s Inequalities.


If that is achievable, then virtually every experiment in quantum physics should be reproducible using just local wave functions.

Does it really make sense that there could be true randomness? Truly uncaused random outcomes? I know it looks like that in quantum physics but how is that even conceptually possible?
Does that even exist in mathematics? I don't mean probability; probability is the mathematics of randomness. I wonder if there are any concepts in mathematics which cause randomness, or from which true randomness can arise. Ex "the answer is either 4 or -4 but not both and not neither." Maybe when physical laws encounter a mathematical construct like this which generates an indeterminate outcome then one possible result just comes into existence from nothing, at the expense of the other. I don't really have a solution, all I know is true randomness is ontologically deep as fuck if it is possible at all.

It seems like quantum randomness probably has some underlying explanation just like the apparent randomness of rolling dice. At least that would be the most conservative guess, since the alternative is so spooky. Doesn't surprise me how strongly Einstein felt about it.

Things only turn out a certain way when we observe them. It's because the universe is all just a computer simulation. And when we look at quantum particles through a microscope, the computer has to come up with some sort of data to show the observer, so it picks some random outcome that appears to have only happened because it was observed.

It's like when you have a date coming over to your house, and you only clean up the rooms they're going to see. Living room, kitchen, bathroom, bedroom. And you leave the rest in total chaos because it doesn't matter. But if you were as fast as a computer, you could go and quickly clean the extra room up the instant they went to peek in there. It's only clean because your date looked in there. If they hadn't looked, it would be chaos.

It's what the "Matrix" (or whatever you want to call it) does with quantum particles. And yes, a tree falling in the woods with nobody to observe it does not make any noise. #LastThursdayism

Quantum mechanics to me always seems like we just don't know enough yet to understand it. If you showed a historic person (Say 12th century) a computer and electricity and technology we have today they wouldn't have a clue how the hell it works or what it is or anything. They would call it magic or witchcraft or the devils work. Quantum mechanics to us is similar to magic. We entangle particles and see that 1 influences another as if by magic. Seems to me like scientists came up with an explanation that sort of fit so they went with it. For example humans used to give sacrifices to prevent bad weather and volcanic eruptions etc because they thought that's how the world worked. There was a god who was unhappy. Then we figured out that it's just part of the earths weather patterns and we now predict changes in weather. One day in the distant future someone will predict the spin of a particle by some new measuring device that measures something we don't understand and it will give them a the correct spin every time they measure it. The universe is too precise. Too perfect to be random. It wouldn't surprise me if we look deep enough in 14 billions years we will know that everything in the universe works on a simple counter that ticks by every tiny amount of time and that number determines everything that has ever and will ever happen.

Note to the Vsauce folks: the concept of "Einstein never accepted the randomness of QM" is more of a hoax than a truth, just like "Einstein made the nuclear bomb" is. The story goes back to the misunderstandings between Max Born and Albert Einstein, who were close friends, but had to communicate by letter during and after the second war. Einstein did understand the concept of randomness, he just did not consider it to be "the final version" of truth, meaning that he considered QM incomplete. Wolfgang Pauli got involved in the exchange between the two giants, and made things clearer. Einstein's formulation of specific QM problems actually paved the way for some of the best explanations. A book was published by Born and his wife about (and including) their letters exchange with Einstein.

It is the innate response of the universe rebelling against its inevitable end: Entropy.

We act like the entire universe, unconsciously, but we are part of its. We believe to be part of an individual, national or world uniqueness, when, in reality, we are the exact replica of everything that is happening in any part of the universe at any scale in a homogeneous way:
"Emergence"

The questions are, What is the limit of complexity? From what line of complexity does there begin to be consciousness? And how much complex is it necessary to get rid of this monotony or for accept it as part of one that cooperates with the universe?

How random is this complexity?

Randomness as an excuse for ignorance.
A growing ignorance closer to us than omniscience.
An omniscience intrinsic to the true meaning of the universe.

The question is: From where does a truly random process divide from another that is not, but this last at the time is composed of an immeasurable quantity of these random processes?

From when do octillions of quantum random probabilities become more or less measurable and predictable processes? Extremely difficult to measure by a person, but that already begin to show patterns that can give (or not) meaning to the universe itself.

The movement of stars and galaxies, the behavior of people, natural phenomena ... everything is made up of the same conglomeration of things that are still considered random today. Is it that we should think of a scale beyond the human scale?

To understand that scale, we would probably need another 100 thousand years of evolution where we would worry more about being eaten by an electron than a lion.

I figured out that there's no such thing as random in 12th grade statistics. There was a problem on a test, about whether there's a fifty percent chance it'll rain tomorrow, since there are only two conditions. I got the question wrong, but I got why: what's going to happen is based on physical forces. But then I thought, wait, couldn't you say the same about a coin toss? The only difference is our ability to predict it.

As for quantum randomness... Yeah, I don't buy it. Because everything we observe is made of those quantum particles. Therefore, if they all operated randomly, wouldn't we live in a universe without cause and effect? Wouldn't there be no patterns whatsoever? Seems like nothing could really take shape that way. I don't really know much about it, but hearing you talk about it... It almost seems to me that the act of observing is what causes the particles to be particles. Like, before that, they're just formless energy. Or something. But anyway, that energy would still follow laws, even if we don't understand them. I feel like it's a form of matter that's just alien to us. We literally can't measure or describe its laws, because it doesn't exist in that form when we observe it.

As for why the word "random" has risen in popularity to describe quirky behavior... I think it has to do with the fact that that kind of behavior is based on following impulses, doing what you feel like, and ignoring social conventions. So, rather than moderating your behavior, acting on feelings, which you can't predict or plan. Supposedly-- a lot of it is calculated to look original, but anyway, being "original" was considered desirable. But anyway, we needed a word for it. "Quirky" doesn't quite fit, because there's still a pattern there, just one that differs from most. The popularity of that behavior had to do with personalities promoted in media, and humor therein, I think... In our culture, we place a lot of emphasis on individuality, but that's always been true. This particular style was popular in the late 90s and early 2000s, it seems. I say "was," because it seems like we're sick of it. We know that people do it on purpose, and it's obnoxious rather than endearing.

Question: Are randomness, and probability really the same thing or separate things? If at any specific time I toss a regular dice that should be random as I have no way influencing the outcome and no knowledge of any imperfection in the dice. It actually should be 100% random in that it nothing could be more random from my unique time and perspective.
There is another perspective, which comes into play if I make multiple throws. To do I must abandon my unique time perspective and enter into an 'on going' perspective. From this perspective all kinds of variables in the condition of dice, my hands, my throw, the air, the landing surface, etc will effect the dice in ways that may inhibit randomness. This second perspective is surely probability, which is by definition never truly random.
So, can true randomness can only occur at a unique point in space-time?
but, isn't it a random proces when a certain patern repeats himself?

Random doesn't exist. It is our simplification of things we do not have a firm grasp of mentally. A coin toss/flip for example is all about physics. How hard was the pressure applied? How fast did it spin? Angle? Velocity? Gravity? Distance? Contact surface? It's this overload of information that combines to make this one normally simple thing appear to have no repoduceable result when in fact it does. The other illusion of random is something that is not in our control. This simplification is necessary.

Cute.  The classic argument for the uncertainty principle and observation problem.  The problem with the uncertainty principle is that we can never directly determine both the position and velocity of a subatomic particle at any given moment because our observations require adding a nontrivial amount of energy into the system thereby changing the behavior of the subatomic particles we want to observe.  Scientists, and indeed most laymen, debate about the meaning and nature of "observation," which is epitomized by Schrodinger's hypothetical cat.  The idea was to challenge the notion of and clarify the nature of observation by linking quantum events with a macro event: a cat in an opaque box being subjected to some sort of poison with a device that's triggered by the decay of a radioactive isotope.  Since we don't know when the atoms will decay, we don't know when the poison will be triggered, and therefore we don't know the life/death state of the cat until we observe it.  So at any given time is the cat alive or dead?  To which a bunch of idiots suggest that it's in a superimposed state where it's both alive and dead at the same time until we open the box, which is nonsense.  This of course has little to do with quantum entanglement or the speed of information transfer, but people go on to conflate those subjects with this all the time as well.  And so quantum mechanics is viewed by many as some mystic, existential, mind-bending subject that only the geniuses among us can understand, when in fact it's just the razor edge of human technology and understanding as we know it which continues to move ever forward and deeper into the unknown.

There were supposedly some Chinese painters - particularly Taoist ones - that attempted to achieve randomness in their paintings. Placing dots and lines without thinking beforehand, " I will put a line here," or without consciously deciding it should be a dot or a line so long or so big or deciding the next strokes orientation in reference to previous ones. Apparently it proved impossible for most. Essentially attempting to apply the Taoist principle of Wu Wei - action without action; action with a selfless, spontaneous quality - to their art. If you attempt to be random you become predictable. Many zen teachers focus heavily on teachings about behaving spontaneously and showing how trying to be spontaneous result in planned spontaneity. An oxymoron. My little philosophical take on randomness for you. Sorry, I'm manic. :p

In order to make predictions, you would have to know the initial conditions. This would require precise measurements, but at the quantum level, you would change the initial conditions with your measurements. Further, your measurements would take time. Even with an infinitely fast computer (faster than Planck time), the initial conditions would change before your "clock" would start running. Further, measuring the state of the system later on to see if it matched your prediction would also change the conditions.

Can we say a coin flip is truly random if we consider the choice of initial conditions part of the experiment? Our conscientiousness comes from our molecular makeup, which includes some quantum uncertainty. This somewhat random and unpredictable conscientiousness feeds into the initial conditions of the coin flip: how we hold the coin, how much force we use, the exact point of contract between finger and coin, etc... So, once the coin is flipped it is physically deterministic, but where we really capture randomness is in the human element, where tiny fluctuations in the initial conditions determine the outcome...

i´m still not convinced there is randomness in quantum mechanics.

To calculate and take in account all tiny influences on a certain object in motion such that we can predict its outcome, like in tossing a coin, is difficult, if not impossible up to the last few flips.

Nevertheless, isn't it that it shows that the forces at hand “know” what to do at any given moment?

We will answer that the forces are blind and do not know as we define knowing, but “How do we know that?”.

But assume that the forces are blind, then how could it ever be possible to “know” a path such that we can predict 100% of the action-result if the forces at hand do not even know what they do????
Maybe it is an illusion that such a calculation can exist other than as a theoretical option. The more because we do not know which unknown forces are at hand too. Or two?

A human's actions are random. I think. If you place a particular human being in a room with four walls, are there enough initial conditions to determine his exact path taken in, say 1 hour? You could argue that knowing every single neuron connection within the brain and his brain chemistry at the time could answer the question, but I don't think even neuroscience has advanced enough to tell us whether those initial conditions could in fact determine his taken path with 100% accuracy.

Some decision making processes in the brain work faster than a "thought". For instance, place both palms face down on a desk and randomly lift up fingers and place them back down, continuously and at a fast pace. You certainly aren't deciding which fingers to move with your brain. The actions are too quick for even you to predict. Some of these actions are perhaps influenced by muscle memory. So maybe a human's actions ARE predictable. But the amount of variables and initial conditions one requires to predict them are near infinite.

Quantum mechanics aside, I think randomness refers to anything we can't understand or predict. As soon as a system's variables become physically impossible for us to predict, the outcome becomes random. The same could even be extended to quantum mechanics where there are possibly initial conditions that we are just ignorant about.

From age 21 to age 50 I was a regular Gambler.  (I quit gambling and drinking at age 50, 8 years ago.)  Any Gambler who plays a LOT of Blackjack or Roulette knows a lot about "Randomness".  Roulette wheels ALL have a bias, but they are so small that it would take several thousand spins of the wheel to detect.  A super computer could easily calculate the odds of a specific number coming up on any Roulette wheel, IF, it could observe several thousand spins of the wheel.  A very well balance Roulette Wheel might be so perfect that it would take 100,000 spins for any "pattern" to be detected, still, it would never be truly "Random".  Gamblers that detect a pattern are usually just fooling themselves.

Hi Vsauce, please read this correction in your assertion that 'if we had all the information we could predict the outcome of the coin toss'. I am an undergrad in physics and for a long time I believed in that assertion...until I took a course on general relativity (although special relativity is sufficient to disprove it).

You see, we have access to all possible influences to the coin toss except......light it self!! There is no way in advance to predict deterministically how many photons will impact the coin as it is tossed because photons have 'world lines' that lie on the edges of our past 'light cones'...to use some relativity speak on a 'null surface.' Or simply, we will never have access to information that propagates at the speed of light itself...which light does obviously. This consideration means that even without quantum randomness, a coin toss would be theoretically impossible the predict.

Quantum theory is a classical example where we have so litle understanding of why something apear random that we even asume it to be a intrinsic part of nature. Random have become the new god. When we asume random is a actual physical property of nature we allso asume there is no possible explenation for what we see. It follows a fallacious mindsett which says: Because I can imagine why this actualy happens, there is no solution.

Random, in normal usage, is the asumption that something doesn't follow a patern (though the irony is that random as a concept in it self is a patern, but that is different story). This concept of random is used when there is more information than what we can- or need to comprehend.
Science in it self asumes there is no such thing as a randomness that is intrincic to nature, that nature in it self can't be random. To asume that random is more than just ignorance and actualy a property of the universe would asume that there are things in nature that ocure with out any physical reason. This is called "acausality" and means simply "the property of not having any cause".
With in logic there is this fallacy called "special pleading". It is when you introduce a special case for perhaps a principle, a law or a theory with out giving a sattisfying explenation why this special case should ocure.
If we don't want to special plead quantum physics as the only system with acausality as a property, we have to asume acausality is a property of everything at any scale. This leads to the absolute break down of physics, because if things can happen for no reason at all, then there is no point of giving explenations to anything.
A nother option would be to asume acausality doesn't exist on any level at all.
The definition of something beeing random is that we do not know the cause for something. If there is no cause, then it is something beyond random.

Great video, as always. This one was especially interesting for me as I am a physicist. Although simplified,  I enjoyed your explanation of the quantum eraser experiment. However, since you always pay attention to detail, one thing might be interesting for you in case you didn't know. There are in fact quite a few theories which postulate that particles don't actually act as random as quantum mechanics (as awesome as it may be) teaches us. One of these theories is the Bohmian mechanics, which basically says that just like with the coin toss particles don't behave randomly at all. It's just that we don't know all the forces that causes them to act wave-like. Now there are some problems with this theory that need clarification like a certain experiment considering the polarisation of photons,  but it's still note worthy, because,  if proven true, there will officially be no true randomness in the Universe. Bummer huh? Personally...  I love quantum mechanics more.

Could it be said to be random if a person were to make a guess on something they don't know?

Say a stranger I'd never met was asked to guess something like the colour of my eyes based on three options, blue, green and brown. What the person would guess could be determined given you had a complete overview of the persons thought process and the chemicals and electrons coming to play in the brain. But I'm suggesting the randomness would instead plainly come from if the answer was right or not, and then you'd have either a positive, or a negative,with no way of telling up front what the result would be, as no one involved actually knows the colour of my eyes or anything else about me.
How about it? Brown would obviously be the safest option to go with as that's the largest part of the worldwide demographic, but I don't see any way that would disrupt the randomness either, because I can be anyone.

I think the parts about misshapen dice and a coin coming up the initial side 51% of the time are misleading.  That just means that the random distribution is not UNIFORM (each result happening equally often).  Something can be random without all results happening uniformly at random (take, for example, the die with 5 5s and 1 blank).
I'm not claiming that Vsauce does not understand this, just that this distinction could have been made more clear.

I think fair and random are not the same. A coin may have a 49% chance of landing one way and 51% of landing the other, but it's still 'random' from our perspective (our perspective being one where we cannot calculate the forces that should allow us to precisely predict the outcome.) It's the fact that the outcome of previous flips do not give us additional information that makes it random, not that it's perfectly fair.

FREE WILL DOES NOT EXIST whether determinism is true or not. Either our wills are determined by prior causes and we are not responsible for them, or they are the product of chance and we are not responsible for them. Imagine if all of your experience were caused by someone at a computer just determining what you feel, do, say and want... that is clearly not a circumstance of free will. Now imagine if that person was determining all of that but 10% of the time threw some dice or introduced some other mode of randomness into the process... that doesn't open up a space for free will. Up until now the notion of free will was used to justify social hierarchy. Dismissing this idea gets you closer to understand reality and makes you more morally sensitive.
Random is an effect without a cause.

Results published recently suggest the De Broglie-Bohm Interpretation (or something much more similar to it than to the Copenhagen Interpretation) is probably correct.  Bohmian mechanics is deterministic with the caveat that you pretty much need to know the complete state of the entire universe to predict things -- rendering it possible in principle but not in practice.  It's explicitly non-local but realist.  Bell says you either have to give up on realism (particles having definite positions) or allow non-local interaction -- what Einstein called spooky action at a distance.   De Broglie found a way to have superluminal influence that doesn't violate relativity because it happens in phase space and doesn't allow actual information transfer. That fits rather neatly with the results of entanglement experiments.

The upshot of that is that nothing is truly random, only intractably chaotic.

All of the current interpretations could be wrong, however. There's more than a dozen and none are believed by a majority of physicists.  Bell could even be based on a subtly invalid premise.  Its logic is internally consistent and it is correct mathematically but if there is a flaw in an axiom it depends on, then it might not be true.  Relativity managed to invalidate the axioms of euclidean geometry so it's certainly possible.  A complete theory of quantum physics may invalidate other axioms and will likely be the result of a very subtle and retrospectively simple shift in perspective as nearly all scientific revolutions are.

Your video was great, however I do have a thought or two. I remember when I was going through High School, mumblemumble years ago, when I learned programming in BASIC to use the RND command which would generate a random number. Only, it wasn’t really random, PCs can’t really generate random numbers. CPUs only work in 1’s and 0’s, the normal operation has to be “known” otherwise there’s bad programming, “illegal operation” error messages, and all that. What the “random” feature of a PC was a list of numbers that was pre-programmed into the OS of numbers that, during a program’s operation, could read off of. However even that was limited as there was only a given list of pre-programmed numbers.
 
So let’s take an example. I tell you to pick a random number between 1 and 10. That’s already a non-random number, there’s limitations on it. If the number picked by a CPU was then therefore 11 say there would be instability. It also assumes a format, such as you might pick “2”. Why not two-and-a-half? It is a number between 1 and 10 isn’t it? There’s an automatic assumption that it’s a whole number instead of fractions or decimal. “My number is 4.2353329801”.
 
Anyway, just a PC logic point-of-view.

You have confused "random" with "uniformly distributed".  Suppose you had a coin that generated heads, then tails, then heads, then tails, etc..  It's not random, but it is uniformly distributed between the possible results (both occur 50% of the time).  Suppose you had a quantum mechanical "coin" that generates heads 75% of the time and tails 25% of the time.  It's random!  It just doesn't have a uniform distribution.

This means that your real coins that bounce and spin and reveal biases - those are still random.  They just have a non-uniform distribution.  Several years ago, Los Alamos demonstrated that predicting coin tosses was impossible if the initial conditions had to be measured closer than quantum-mechanical precision.  And the math showed this to be a reasonably attainable situation provided you drop (or throw) the coin on a nearly elastic surface so that it bounces (high enough to flip) more than a few times.  Sure, a biased coin will have a non-uniform distribution, but it will still really be random.  So, throw your coins on a concrete pad - and bounce them around a lot.  (The same with dice if you guarantee at least four bounces or so....)

The fundamental randomness of quantum mechanics has been used to generate random numbers by shooting a laser through a thin slit.  This is taught in every advanced physics class - you don't know whether each photon will bend left or right.  Place an optical pick-up on the receiving end and each hit becomes a bit.  You can run this at high speed, streaming the 0's and 1's out with a data cable.  I think that's as random as you can get with a connection to a computer. I would say "randomness" is just the propogation of a specific set of information that can not be decoded/predicted faster than it propogates.  Essentially the entirety of the universe would be random on an absolute macro scale, wherin nothing from within the universe can predict every outcome, position, energy state etc.  Even if you knew the initial conditions of the universe you still would not be able to predict with absolute certainty the propogation of the way all the information is going to turn up. Obeying conservation laws.  On a smaller scale a simple machine spitting out lotery type numbers could not be processed on the spot could be considered random to us because the machine would/could be putting out numbers faster than we can predict.  We are not totally powerless in prediction, obviously.  For instance we can track the path of a baseball and catch it with some degree of certainty using information we process both consciously and unconsciously.  Even though on a small scale we actually catch the ball before we have even processed that we caught it, leaving an ever so small hint of randomness or unpredictably with every bit of information we process.

I liked this video quite a bit, but still have a criticism.

The center section of the video seems to conflate randomness with chance probability.  Examples of when the probability of an event is not the reciprocal of the number of events (e.g., a coin that doesn't come out heads 50% of the time, ignoring landing on edge) has nothing to do with whether the process is random.  To even suggest this could cause quite a bit of misunderstanding in viewers.  There are truly stochastic processes with non-reciprocal probabilities; there are deterministic processes with reciprocal probabilities.  They are independent issues.

The only reason to bring up chance in a discussion about randomness is when you want to relate the issue to the technical meaning of "information," maybe to make the point that even random events are informative.  If chance is not the reciprocal, then you can't use the equation to calculate information (H) - that is, you can't use the log of the number of events.  But if you aren't going to talk about information, then I would only bring up chance to make the opposite point to what's in the video - that is, to show that the shape of the distribution of probabilities has nothing to do with whether the process is random.

Also, as the above might suggest, I greatly prefer the word "stochastic" to "random," partly because "random" has much too much baggage, while "stochastic" is new to most folks (and, therefore, comes baggage-free).  My experience of lecturing on this to college undergrads has taught me that first explaining what a stochastic process is will get most folks to an understanding very quickly.  I often end by saying that stochasticity is one of the meanings of "random," but the latter has so many other meanings that the word is losing its value, so I don't use it.

The hole idea of random interests me. Take the idea of...I dont, Drops in an online game. An item, may only have a fixed 5% chance of appearing when you kill a specific something.....ok, so if I kill that specific something 20 times, I am pretty much guaranteed that drop. but that does not happen. ok,  so thats unlucky, what if I killed that specific something 60 times....still not drop. right now, that 5% chance seems to be a lie. statistically, I am so unlucky, that I exist outside the system of what should happen if we consider people receiving the drop as a Normal Distribution. (also depends on how they calculate that randomness)

now, random number generators on computer are not that random, infact, they are statistically calculable and even, predictable. Computers generally apply by something called Perfect Randomness. if I use a random dice generator and get a 6, I have a 1/6 chance of getting a 6 again. but the computer will ever so incredibly rarely throw out another 6, almost actively avoiding it.. use any number generator and the chance of getting 3 numbers is a row, I wager is statistically much lower than True Randomness.

Are quantum mechanics really random?
Consider this- Viewing something is NOT a passive action, it absorbs and destabilizes  whatever was happening.
You cannot feel or sense something without interacting with it in some way, you absorb energy from it.

Because the smallest things we are currently aware of can only be seen by disturbing them, we currently have no way to know the true nature of things left untouched.

So maybe the universe is perfectly predictable, we just can't look at it on the quantum level without disturbing things. A given system can't be perfectly aware of itself because the layering of systems leads to further simplifications - A brain cannot be perfectly aware of its entirety because the neurons are so much bigger than the things those neurons are made of.

Hey Vsauce, I have a question that has been nagging me for some time, and I can't seem to find any satisfactory answer. It's about probabilities, and in a way, randomness.
Let's illustrate the problem I have been struggling with. Imagine you go to a casino. In that casino, there's a game where you roll dice and bet on which number you will get (I'm keeping it pretty simple). So basically, you bet on a number from 1 to 6, you roll a dice (die ?) and you get the money if you're right.

Now right away, you would think that you get a 1/6 chance to win. But... is it, really ? Because we also know that, for instance, rolling 10 times in a row the same number is EXTREMELY rare. So if you arrive at the casino, watch people play and the number 6 appears 4 times in a row, and then decide to play - should you rather NOT bet on the number 6 ? Have the probabilities changed ?

To go even further, imagine you have the same scenario, except you DIDN'T see the previous results (but the number 6 still rolled 4 times in a row) - what happens then if you bet on the number 6 ? To you, it's just a 1/6 chance just like any other number - but to the people who were there before and have seen the previous results, it's not, since they know that it has already been 6 quite a few times ? Maybe true randomness can only have meaning in the context of non-randomness.  We can only make sense of what randomness means by looking at something in a procedural or orderly way.  We look at a number like 387143298 usually reading it from left to right and seeing if there is a pattern.  But why not look at it starting from the middle?  Or from the right?  We chose to look at the number in an orderly way, and then sought to determine if it followed a pattern when we looked at it in that particular way.

Irrational numbers, like the square-root of 2, have no repeating pattern.  This seems to mean that despite the result being random, there is a non-random procedure that can be followed to give this random result.  So is it really random?  True randomness could only really exist if there existed no patterns and no procedure.  But in trying to analyze whether or not a series of numbers like 31894732432149 is random or not, we automatically start looking at it from left to right as if each element is listed in that procedural order, which then defeats the purpose of looking for randomness.  Randomness can only then be seen in this list of numbers if we don't consider any order to it, and simply observe each number in the series as standing alone, without any particular ordering with respect to the rest.

Or perhaps the only possible difference between randomness and non-randomness is whether or not a pattern can be discerned when the procedure that is producing a result is unknown.  This is the case with the irrational numbers.  The result of square root of 2 is essentially random, as long as you don't realize that I am producing the result by following a procedure for calculating square root of 2.

You call something commonly called random not random, by saying we could predict the outcomes of something if we tried hard enough, and you're right.
However, I will a randomly generated sequence of numbers below:
284196, 96.3584, 415689, 286, 14, 548, 5683, 1468, 8, 368254, 14

Are you telling me that these numbers aren't random? Well, they are, because these numbers were generated with no patterns, no regard for thought, and were put here without my full intentions. You could argue that my hand was able to be put on the keyboard in predictable ways, but I covered my hands in order to make them non-tangible to the keyboard, therefore I could not possibly have any remote idea what buttons my fingers. After that, I covered my eyes, placed my hand on the arrow keys, and placed a comma and a space between whatever it landed on.

My point is, that if I couldn't predict it, the very one who created the basis for this argument, then it is truly random, because of the lack of intention.

Actually all that quantum mechanics stuff isn't random. If you knew the location and velocity of all the subatomic particles in an atom you could calculate with a 100% accuracy where all the particles would be 1 second from now given the forces from other atoms and stuff don't interfere with the atom. The only reason why it seems random is because the observing equipment isn't infinitely sensitive and the inner working of matter aren't 100% understood. The only way to get true randomness would be using time travel and paradoxes. If I had a device which received a signal from one second in the future and sent a signal back in time with the exact same information one second later then it would be sending the exact same signal that it originally received. There would be no way whatsoever to predict whether or not the signal would be "a" or "g". That is true randomness.

The idea that Quantum Physics(and Evolution by Natural Selection) is "random" seems to be a pretty universal misunderstanding of those two sciences. In fact, both processes are the polar opposite of random. Quantum Physics is easily the least random science there is; the predictability and accuracy of the theory is second to none. And while genetic mutation IS random...Natural Selection is NON-random. If Natural Selection was random...adaptation would be impossible.

But yeah...easy mistakes to make(which luckily Vsauce didn't make in this video). Then again, personally, I question the entire idea that "randomness" is even real, let alone a valid possibility. In a truly deterministic universe(which we have every reason to assume IS the case with our universe), true randomness is an impossibility. True randomness would cascade outward...propagating until the entire universe became nothing but an undifferentiated mess of low-entropy white noise.

My own hunch is that, just like the beginning of the universe, the end of the universe is book-ended by a singularity...a singularity which draws space-time-energy-matter into higher and higher entropic states. Teilhard de Chardin and Terence McKenna were big proponents of this idea....and I'm inclined to agree with them. Interesting topic for sure...

I can explain this whole thing very simply, at least this is how I've personally reasoned it to work. I've had some people provide different theories that I am not yet able to grasp, but that's another conversation altogether. Feel free to add insight, agree, or disagree professionally:


From what I've reasoned, we live in a base 2 universe, meaning everything is inherently binary. Every single thing you can think of can be somehow represented as on/off, 1,0, up/down, so on and so forth.

So the formula I've come up with to explain this is X=+-1.
That can be read two ways:
1. X equals plus AND minus 1,
2. X equals plus OR minus 1.

#1 is the actual static state of the universe. #2 is what we are. #1 and #2 are both the same thing, it only has 1 feature, and that's the ability to create the illusion of separation.

Does this make sense to anyone but me, or is it crazy talk?

Well, there is this thing that is (and I quote) "truly random". It's called the one-time pad. The one-time pad is a ciphering system slightly comparable to the Caesar Wheel, albeit for each individual letter. Say you have this message: ESBES. Now, because the person burned the pad containing the key (hence it's name), it's impossible to know what it says (11,881,376 possible combinations). For all you care, it could be Helen, there, hello, or any other 5 letter words.

A lot of people don't seem to know what randomness means.
I mean, for one example, a lot of people call their sense of humor random. This irks me because it's not random, but rather spontaneous, 'purple monkey dishwasher' or batshit insane.

It functions based upon some kind of predictable pattern. For example, kumquat cupcake refrigerator shoelace. There's some kind of pattern there, that string of seemingly random words has some basis in reality and predictability. Truly random humor wouldn't even be recognizable as humor, it would just be a completely formless mass of what may be words, numbers, sounds, and objects.

I think 'random' doesn't always mean unpredictable, it also means improbable. For example, I went hiking once with my girlfriend and 'randomly' ran into her cousins on the hike. The fact that we both decided to go at the right time, on the right day, on the right trail, and it's the first time I've ever been hiking, EVER is pretty random. There is absolutely no way you can calculate the next time and place we will all end up on the same hiking trail at the exact time and location again without planning it.

Quantum 'Relational' theory, single dimensional values that are shared by their respective similarities is what causes quantum entanglement to 'share' information when a process is observed. That is when you are related to something its hard to brake that relation because every thing you do is at a quantum level measured and filled in by quantum processes. So when you observe you are turning on the relation and when you ignore you are leaving the relation to something else. This holds true at every level of physics, not just the quantum.. but it just seems spooky that distance (a three dimensional observation) is ignored and relation (the sharing of that information in a single dimension) is preferred.

I had a long conversation with someone that doesn't solve a Rubik's Cube (I'm a cuber).  He argued that if he were to 'randomly' turn faces he would eventually solve it.  I argued that once he saw pieces going into place it's no longer random.  Because he would SEE it's not random anymore.  

I calculated (somewhat calculated) with other cubers that it would take on average 176 billion years at a rate of 5 turns per second (that's fast) for a person to randomly turn a Rubik's Cube into a solved state.  That is if the person turning the layers is blindfolded and another person watches then stops him/her from turning when it is solved.  

The average is 176 billion years... but it could take anywhere from 2 seconds to not infinitely long.

I met her on omegle. It always terrified me, to think that my life could have been shaped and determined by something... random. It bothered me to think that God could have played dice with something so important... to think that this was not planned ahead, like the page 72 of a book whose page 34 I'm reading.
I've always wanted to think that every particle in the universe had a course that could be predicted from the instant of the big bang, and that both page 1 and page 72 were printed on the same day. I wanted to believe that who I am, what the world is and what I'm doing right now is just a consequence of a consequence of a consequence... I wanted to believe that she was intended...
But I couldn't because I thought that a computer's randomness algorithm was somehow based on quantum physics.
Now I know it's not. Atmosphere and stuff. Good to know.
So remains the hope that somehow we got it wrong. The hope that quantum physics do not exhibit true randomness, just a pattern we're not wise enough to comprehend.
Yet.

The word GOD might simply be a Human extrapolation of the concept of consciousness. We Human tend to extrapolate from what we see and experience. Thus, extrapolating the experience of consciousness could potentially lead to the creation of the GOD concept expressing a consciousness so advanced and powerful that it can "know" everything and "act" on the world way further than we do. We are already acting on matter in unpredicted and unprecedented ways: we literally created fundamentals particles at the CERN! Our individual consciousness are not so powerful: most people can only think with only a few ideas at the same time (7 at most). But by the way human societies evolved, we are collectively creating an higher consciousness by the way we collaborate, create, share and interact with always larger amount of information. Maybe we are slowly but surely closing the gap with the GOD concept we have been praising for so long. Some people will point out that GOD is more values-oriented (what is good, what is bad), but this is again an embodiment within a word of our extrapolation of what is moral and what is not.

This text, being seen as an element of absolute improbability, is a completely random string of letters... Until you saw it written down. Of course, it's not completely random in a sense, the person writing this only has 106 different combinations of button presses to achieve different predetermined values to make legible and understandable English text. So, that being the case, anyone that knows the person writing this would be able to predict what they wrote even before they wrote it or it was read. Someone who doesn't know the person writing this wouldn't even be absolutely sure that I am a male, sure, the videos on my channel and my Profile Picture all show the same person, but you, in your position right now, cannot be certain that I even exist, as your entire exposure to me has been filtered through so much technology that looking at it would be unrecognizable.

Look at the piece of words that tells you how long ago this was written. It may say thirty seconds, 6 hours, 3 days, or even 20 years, but this text didn't exist in your reality, until you read it. How can you be positive that that little grey piece of text is reliable or not? Sure every time you look at it the time will always, if a bit vaguely, refer back to the exact time this was published, but in all cases, this text couldn't have possibly existed until you bared witness to it's existence. Sure someone else might say that this text is pretty cool and you should read it, but it didn't really exist until you actually read it.

When someone tells you to read something, there is a 50% chance that you will actually read it. You mightn't be in the position at that time to search it up reducing the likelihood that you will read it, but then again, you might have a smartphone on you at all times so you will always be in a position to read it, but then you might be out of range of any cellular or internet up-link areas, reducing the chance, but then you might have payed a lot of money for you to be able to connect to the internet wherever you are... but then your phone might be dead. There are unlimited variables possible for there to be any more, or any less than a 50% chance that you, anyone, or anything will do something.

For example, reaching the end of this text. That is a chance on it's own. You might get bored about halfway through and stop, you might have already read something similar to this before, so you left or you might even lose the ability to read this before you even get to the end of this text (power outage, screen malfunction, computer virus, a sudden case of severe dyslexia), so technically speaking, there is a very low chance that you will get this far... but then you have now haven't you? Otherwise you wouldn't be reading this now.

I mean look how far you've gone in reading this text, so far, four paragraphs have passed and about 3-5 minutes of reading has gone out of your way. I can type literally anything here that I want, because something this far down couldn't exist with you pushing the 'Read More' button and taking the time out of your day to read all the way down here. So anything that you haven't read so far, is a complete and total enigma. There isn't even a solid chance that I can finish what I'm typing for you to read it. I mean, what happens if my browser crashes? Then where would you be?

Well, you wouldn't be reading this for one thing. In fact, the only person, right now that will lose anything if this isn't finished correctly is me... because I have now spent 10 or so minutes of my time writing this. Where would I be then if I can't finish this? Well, I'd be pretty annoyed, now wouldn't I?

Now, look back, to the top of this monster of a wall of text, and remember what I typed about how this can only literally be an improbable string of only 106 different combinations of keystrokes. What did I really mean by that? Well, the keyboard I have now has about 53 different keys to push:

`1234567890-=qwertyuiop[]\asdfghjkl;'zxcvbnm,./ and Enter, but also everything again, but with shift pushed.

~!@#$%^&*()_+QWERTYUIOP{}|ASDFGHJKL:"ZXCVBNM<>?

And I could quite simply just push any random string of those characters... but is it really random? At this point, it is, because right now, at the time of writing this the string that I have planned to write is absolutely up to chance... but is it? I could chose anything, the combination is fluctuating constantly in my mind right now. I'm thinking of a million different combinations of letters in my mind right now, but then, is it so random? I mean I could chose anything, so why don't I exploit this? The power of the control over your interest, I mean I wouldn't have your interest right now, if you didn't read this far. You wouldn't even know that I was gunning for the control of your interest if you didn't read this far.

So right now, at this moment, your interest is mine for what ever I wish, but is it really? Nothing but your interest, you computer's reliability and your middle finger is keeping you here. A simple press of the backspace key would make you go back a page and I would lose all of your interest, because you are not here anymore. Although, you still haven't done it yet, because you're still here reading, but can I really say that? How can I know that you haven't pressed backspace and then simply hit the forward button and scrolled down back to here to continue reading? The answer is, I don't, but it's a possibility.

Ideas on why "random" is "misused":
- The drive for amazement. Calling unlikely things "random" implies that the space of possibilities is packed with unlikely things. This is motivating.
- Great for communications. Claiming that you know of an "odd" event may backlash if the listener finds a reasonable pattern. If the listener doesn't find one, his intellectual self-confidence may suffer. "Random" insists that no pattern should be sought for.
- Ironic elitism. Well-crafted weirdness called "random" creates the claim that such things happen often, with no effort etc. Calling someone's work "random" this way is an accolade. It's not bragging as both the praiser and the praisee understands the truth. People who don't see this can be pushed out as stupid, especially teachers and such.

Okay, no. Whether or not a particular radioactive isotope will decay is based off of the sheer fact, that it is radioactive. Radioactive means that the weak interaction affects the substance and will cause it to decay, whether that be be via alpha, beta, or gamma decay. We can calculate the half-life of a substance. There is no randomness, it is an existing constant. Constants such as Plank's constant and Avagadro's "mole." They're not random, they're values. And the spin of an electron is a value. On the predictability of atmospheric noise:

I'm not entirely sure that that is entirely correct. The exact angle and acceleration of atoms in the air bouncing off of each other is dependent on the observed position of electrons, the decay of the chance radioactive molecules in the air and on its obstructions, the appearance of virtual particle-antiparticle pairs which immediately self-destruct, the exact behavior of particles in the sun which are fusing to emit light and light which is being re-emitted by particles at seemingly random angles and intervals over the course of tens or hundreds of millennia.

Over a long enough period, we should see even relatively large-scale weather systems change. If we looked billions of years back and re-ran the universe under the exact same conditions except for those involving true randomness such as that quantum mechanics, it might even be likely that Hurricane Katrina would have had a different overall windspeed, timing, damage, etc.

Furthermore, lifeforms may be somewhat truly random as well. Why exactly a synapse in the brain fails to fire a large fraction of the time is not well-understood, but may have a lot to do with non-deterministic quantum-mechanical effects.

Hypothetically, a computer processor with a half-pitch under 5 nm would have a significant chance of quantum tunneling causing a glitch in a value. If it happens in a critical part of the software, it may cause the computer to crash and the fans to stop running. Fans not running could definitely create a substantial amount of randomness in global atmospheric phenomena, especially due to their highly chaotic, ultra-sensitive nature.

Point is, in the short run, human-scale and large-scale air movements are highly predictable. In the long run, they are effected by true randomness.

Innate randomness does not and cannot exist.  All things have causes regardless of our ability to predict them.  The only randomness is in the inability for humans to predict something such as the spin of an electron prior to measurement.

This does not mean that the electron's spin is purely random, it means that we will likely be forever unable to predict any particular electron's spin prior to measurement.

This does not mean that "nothing" caused it or that it is not determined by something else, it means that we have reached a wall.  We have reached a wall in our ability to predict.

That's about as random as we'll ever get.  There is no "true" randomness.
