How can we say that it is 100% of the time? If I flip a coin, say I want tails, and it lands heads, I am always 100% wrong. But if I do it again, and get tails, I am right 50% of the time. Even if we flip a coin over 9000 times, and get heads, we can't say we will get heads 100% of the time. There is always the chance it may land tails. Even with those robots. A small gust of wind, a slight malfunction etc. could always give the other result. Also, from which point did they start measuring getting the correct results? From the first ever build of the robot, or from the newest? The oldest build will have got some wrong, but still have got some right. The scientists are still predicting the coin toss, so even with calculations, they are still predicting without being fully sure. It could be pure coincidence that they are always getting the right results. Their presence as observers will change the outcome, and they will get what they expect/want from the experiment, as they will accidentally change things. People normally prove things right, as they have one mindset, and when the results are different from what they want, they say it is wrong and change it. When they do get what they wanted from the experiment, they call it to a stop and use it as confirmation, even if they have done something wrong. We can never be 100% sure, as everything is more complex and random than we may ever think.

Quantum theory only works as an instrument of randomness if and only if the Copenhagen Interpretation is true or one of the indeterministic minority interpretations is true. The Copenhagen Interpretation and the Many Worlds Interpretation, both of which are the two main interpretations of quantum theory physicists use, are experimentally indistinguishable from each other. If the Many Worlds Interpretation is right, the world is fully deterministic and nothing is random. However, we do not know which of these two, or even if it is one of these two, interpretations is right. It could be one of the minority interpretations or it could be something no one has thought of yet. So far, though, all we can say on the matter is: We don't know.

Actually some recent research suggests that the bias in spinning pennies is not due to the head being the heavier side. The authors find that due to the forces causing a penny to flip which side is up while it spins, the heavier side has a tendency to turn up. They authors also found that the bias in pennies is more significant in those made before the mint switched to a horizontal press. Unfortunately I don't have the article on hand nor is it online, but it was in a recent issue of the Pi Mu Epsilon journal.

I don't think that it's helpful to talk about "true randomness". It gets into a pointless, dead debate about determinism versus randomness, and as it turns out, the universe defies such lazy categories. The video got into chaos theory a little bit, but ultimately what it shows is that, even in non-quantum systems, it's mathematically impossible to have enough information to predict certain systems beyond the short term (e.g. the weather). Heisenberg's uncertainty principle is just a lower limit to our ignorance, a foil to finding all the information even when we have all the exact building blocks. And yet, all of these "random" processes are just a consequence of deterministic laws and principles. The universe is both deterministic and random.
In the (not exact) words of Niels Bohr: "Einstein, will you stop telling God what to do!?"

I personally don't like the term "look" in a quantum state measurement sense. It implies the will or the act of looking at something when, in fact, the results are "fixed" (or discovered) in the moment the measurement is taken, as it will happen in any kind of interaction with that particle. No will or action involved.
Saying that things happen when we "look" implies a certain human-centrism – that we have some kind of control over that process – which is not the case. And this kind of human-centrism can, will and have lead lots of people to believe in a lot of bullshit pseudoscience. (see: deepak chopra, oprah winfrey, what the blip do we know, the secret)

TL;DR: Saying things happen when we look is imprecise and harmful. Please stop.

There's an interesting difference to be stated between the existence of patterns, or even our ability to find them, and predictability or determinism.
We can calculate Pi or sqrt(2) or many other irrational numbers to any precision we want (so the process of obtaining theses sequences of digits is prefectly deterministic), yet we can prove that there is no pattern inside Pi. That particular sequence of numbers, the decimal expansion of Pi, is at the same time predictable and completely devoid of any compressibility.

If we want to be really precise, Pi is not so much predictable as it is calculable. It's not an event or a phenomenon we're observing to check whether we guessed its outcome right. It's just a static object that happens to be infinitesimally observable.

That pretty much proves that humans don't have a free will: we are only a product of our environment. 

Imagine we had a computer that could take all these variables of what being a human means, everything you were born with and everything you have experienced (= everything that has ever influenced you). This computer could accurately predict the future and every human decision. That means we might have a decision but we don't necessarily get to chose how we decide. Everything is pre-destined; Even though there might be several possible outcomes only one will actually happen and everything that happens has to happen.

That doesn't mean you can lie down and wait for your destiny to happen; If you did that your destiny would be that you lie down and do nothing which again will result in, well, nothing.

We can never know our destiny though because if we had such a complex computer that could tell us our destiny the fact that we are reading it and know about it is another variable. The destiny would be that we read something that would have been the destiny if we hadn't read the destiny. Then something else would be the destiny.

We are not responsible for our deeds. Nontheless, penalties and reactions by other humans are also exactly what has to happen. They don't have a choice either.

The problem is, quantum mechanics takes place in the quantum vacuum. The quantum vacuum is not absolute void of any being - it's a rich sea of energy WITHIN our universe's bounds, still governed by our universe's physical laws, and capable of producing ongoing fluctuations of particles coming into and out of existence. So the quantum fluctuations may be predetermined by the quantum energy fields/forces, rather than be completely random... Resultant movement doesn't occur where there is no prior force, and something can't come from nothing (ex nihilo nihil fit) - assuming so would be to assume the violation of many already well-established physical laws. I'm not saying true randomness doesn't exist, rather that the quantum vacuum (while intuitively attractive) is probably not the best place to find it xD

There is a great book series by Isaac Asimov "Foundation". The premise of the series is that the mathematician Hari Seldon spent his life developing a branch of mathematics known as psychohistory, a concept of mathematical sociology (analogous to mathematical physics). Using the laws of mass action, it can predict the future, but only on a large scale; it is error-prone on a small scale. It works on the principle that the behaviour of a mass of people is predictable if the quantity of this mass is very large (equal to the population of the galaxy, which has a population of quadrillions of humans, inhabiting millions of star systems). The larger the number, the more predictable is the future.

I would say that randomness within an uneven distribution is just as random as without. Let's say you have a coin with a 51% chance of landing on heads. Yes, this gives you a greater ability than 50% to predict the next outcome, but there isn't a pattern you can follow. If you thought you had identified a pattern, you could test to see if you could correctly predict more than 51% of a sufficiently large number of flips. If not, there is no pattern, despite the bias.

When i played table top wargames, i was able to work out a "flick roll" type thing where i had my forefinger under the dice, thumb on top. And whatever number was on my finger (ie, a 6 pointing down) would normally be the number that landed face up on the table. :P I did some tests, 100 rolls to be exact, and of them 73 were the number i had facing down, the one i was trying to roll. Not exactly a huge test, not enough rolls made, but for a 15 year old, i was fairly impressed with myself that i went to all that work. 

:P it got to the point where the "rule referees" at the local club asked me to roll my dice "like a normal person" instead of the one at a time flick i was doing. Safe to save my "winning" streak ended about there. haha.

Whether or not it was truly me, or just luck i can't say, but it definately felt like i was getting the number i wanted a lot more when i rolled with that method, and i feel my test backed it up.

Hey Michael, Big question here. 
Hypothetically speaking, what if we were given a precise "map" of the universe at the moment of the big bang? Included in this "map" would be the locations and spin on all of the elections in existence at that original moment. In this example, human beings have advanced far enough to be able to measure the speed and location of electrons well enough to be able to track them through the billions of years of expansion and change the universe has undergone. Supposing we ever achieve this feat, could it then be said that nothing is truly random, as we could plug the massive amount of original data into our hugely advanced and complicated equation, to arrive with a precise answer of how we can expect any one electron to be acting at any particular moment? Should this be true, then could one say that nothing innately random - but only seemingly is random due to our ignorance in this field (in this case being quantum mechanics)?
Thank you for taking the time to consider this. Keep on doing the amazing work you do.

I strongly disagree that anything, even on the quantum level, could be truly random. Don't get me wrong, I've done no actual study into this so I really don't know what I'm talking about, so if you could enlighten me that'd be great, but for instance, if our observations make the result, then perhaps our means of observing is interfering with the results. Perhaps it's the case that we can't observe something without interfering with the results, but that still doesn't make it truly random.

Whatever the case, I currently believe that we have no real idea of what's going on in these experiments, and what we see appears to be random, but in actual fact there are mechanics at work that we simply don't understand yet.

The quantum entanglement and apparent 'spooky action' is so easy to explain it is beyond frustrating how much this process is misunderstood and misrepresented.

To entangle/measure a pair of particles means to set their chosen quantum number to opposite/anti-correlated values. If we then leave those particles alone i.e. do not disturb the system they remain in sync/in opposition to themselves until we again decides to measure/entangle one of them with the environment.

Once we do that we discover its state and by definition the other particle has to be in the opposite state - absolutely no mystery here.

To better visualize this think of two 12 hour analog clocks. Entanglement/measurement means that we set one of the clocks for example to 6 o'clock and the other then has to be set to 12 o'clock. Then we cover them with two identical cloths i.e. isolate the system to prevent measurement/de-coherence.

Provided we do not reset i.e. measure any of those clocks again, we can wait as long as we want not even counting the time passed and we can still be sure that once we peek under one cloth i.e. measure the state of one clock, that the other clock will show exactly the opposite hour on it's dial. We measure 3 o'clock, the other one will show 9 o'clock.

In real life one might use atomic clocks and once relativistic effects kick in, even when perfectly isolated, the spontaneous de-coherence of the clocks should be roughly proportional to the relative speed of the clocks and difference of gravitational potential between their positions.

The question then shifts from how does one particle knows the state of the other one - it does not, they are both synchronized/anti-correlated from the beginning - to how does that happen that they become anti-correltated at the initial entanglement. I am not a physicists, though if I was forced to guess, I would bet on some aspect of energy conservation.

Of course I can be wrong and all above is fluff. This however, is a rather easy experiment to do, especially with current technology. I really hope someone smarter than me will do it someday, so that I won't have to - I am such a lazy person :P

The fact that patterns and biases can be found even within randomness seemingly suggests that the only truly useful definition of the word "random" is simply "I cannot predict" rather than "without cause". Therefore, whether you consider something random is a matter of whether you personally can see the pattern or not. As such, randomness then becomes not really an objective thing, but a subjective one.

Not really the same thing, but it reminds you of how "perfect" (in the practical sense) means "finished" as opposed to "without flaw" since what is flawless to one person may be disastrously bad to someone else. So when we say something is "perfect" what we really mean we're done fiddling with it. Similarly, if we say something is  "random" we probably just mean "there may be a reason, but I'm not seeing it."

Scientists always talk about the universe....but there isn't one universe to be talked about, there's my universe, and there's your universe, based on our different perceptions. In my universe, I see a man who chose not to get a college education so that he could support his family. In your universe, you see a man who couldn't get a college education, so that he could support his family. In my universe, the man is noble, but in yours he is unfortunate.

In the case of randomness, I also have a different view than Michael. He says that as long as you can explain something, it is not technically random, but I say that is not true. You see, just because you can explain that I had to go to the bathroom, doesn't mean it's not random. I had to go to the bathroom, because I drank a glass of tea a few hours ago, because I wanted something to drink, because my body was dehydrated, because (and so on and so forth). You can keep going, but Me having to go to the bathroom, is only the end of a twig on a tree of what could have happened, all starting with the beginning of the original universe. If almost nothing is random, we would be able to predict the future, and the things like lotto tickets, the weather, sports games, would all be predetermined 100% of the time. The more variables you add to something, the more random it becomes, and for that I say, it's random that I'm typing a long message about the universe and randomness as a comment for a video about randomness on a website that features user created videos made with video recording devices by a company that came up with the idea based on an invention blah blah blah. Life is random, even if you can predict it as close to 100% as possible.

Not to start any argument about religion, but rather just to counter-point, you can always go deeper with the question.  Saying that Lady Luck created the universe is a large assumption, but it is not so big of an assumption to say that Lady Luck disorganized the universe.

When you go deeper when the questions, you come up with, "Who or what placed energy inside of nothing?"  "If it's God, where did God come from?"

I think a lot of us agree that everything was organized at one time (particularly the beginning of time);  But why did everything that exists today, exist in an organized fashion at one time?  What caused this organized matter to eventually disorganize constantly to this day?

But, if you watch your alarmclock at any given time, the probability of seeing 11:11 is greater than any other number. People took that seriously before it was disproved. In fact, some things seem to happen more often because you remember it easier ; this is known as selective memory.
When you're watching at the digital clock and you're seeing hours like 12:47 or 19:34, your brain don't pay attention to them and delete them.
When you see 11:11, your brain says : "Wow, that's odd :)" and those information become more memorable. There's also 22:22 but most people are in bed. ;)
That's why we only pay attention to non-random objects, patterns, information, etc...

To use biased coins to get unbiased random bits, you can use Von Neumann's elegant solution: flip the biased coin twice, if both results are different try again, otherwise use the result of the first flip. If the coin is heavily biased you will have to repeat more often, but the procedure works: it eliminates any (constant) bias, without even having to know what the bias actually is.

Randomness is actually way more simple than you're making it sound. While it's true that if we could know the exact conditions it would take to make a coin land on heads every time the only condition that's actually important is that we want it to land on heads every time. A normal coin flip is still technically random because we have no control over which side it's going to land on. The chances of one side over the other don't necessarily have to be 50/50 to qualify as random. It only really stops being random when we can predict the outcome and we would only be able to predict the outcome because it will land on the side that we want it to. That's not even really a true prediction because we've decided which side it will land on before we even made the coin flip. It's a decision, not a prediction. Basically anything that we don't have any control over, anything we didn't contentiously calculate and decide before hand, is random. So you could never truly predict the result of a coin toss because you can't know the outcome without calculating and deciding what that outcome will be. Anything that happens without intelligent thought, that is not calculated and decided by a thinking mind, is random. That being said the example you gave of running into someone you know at a popular club is not random because you both decided to go there. You may of had no way of knowing you were going to see each other there but the fact that you both made a deliberate decision to be there means it isn't just some random event though running into them in a crowded place when you had no idea they would be there is. You didn't plan on meeting them there so it's technically both random and calculated at the same time. It is possible for two people who know each other to be in the same place without ever seeing each other there. A few weeks ago I was at Wal Mart with my ex except we never planned to meet there, had no idea we were both there at the same time, and never actually saw each other while we were there. The chances of running into someone you know are kind of random unless you actually planned to meet there. You have to be able to calculate every variable for something to stop being random, including the interference of other people.

The thing that bugs me the most about Random on computers, is the fixed distribution.. 

if you collect samples of random between 0 and 100, and collect 1.000.000 samples, the distribution is almost precisely 10.000 pr digit = evenly distributed. 

i struggle to call that random, true random shouldn't be evenly distributed - but of cause, evenly distributed random is better to use in computers, because of their practicality. 

Random noise also have that property, mailny because random noise always have a spectrum = min / max values... At best it will produce a gauss curve.

Computer type random, also almost never produce the same number twice in a sequence, how can that be random ?

And lastly - the story of the infinite monkeys on typing machines, would never produce anything readable - the entropy of their randomness isn't capable of producing anything but short words / sentences.

Is quantum space really random though? Or do we just not understand it?

Consider a thought experiment. You have a device which can rewind time, allowing you to move back and forth at will.

If you drop something and watch it hit the floor, then rewind and watch it again, the exact same events will play out, since all the conditions are the same.

If you could then, theoretically, measure the electron state of a particle at a precise moment, and then rewind time, and measure that moment again, would that state be different?

If not, then it can't be truly random, because something is dictating whether it stays the same or not, even if it's completely unpredictable and beyond understanding.

But if it was different, then that seems pretty conclusive that it's a fully random event.

If that were true though, wouldn't there be some chance that rewinding time might sometimes result in different events, even if all the initial stimuli were exactly the same?

If some event happening is reliant on some quantum state, and quantum states are truly random, then there should be some instances where the exact same stimuli in the same environment and the same time flow would produce different results.

Just something to think about.

Computers usually calculate random numbers from a time seed that's generally the microseconds elapsed from Epoch time, it means the time elapsed from 1st January 1970 according to UTC, but some seeds calculate it from the clock counter that's the time elapsed from when the computer powered on. Let's assume at one time it's 600.458148452 seconds (600458148452 nanoseconds) so you can convert it to a more precise value like 600.458148452*1000=600458.148452 and you trim the decimal value so you get 0.148452 that changes over time so you get milliseconds between 0.0 and 0.999999. A millisecond is the thousandth of a second, but if we look at the decimal value as whole we are still in the precision of a nanosecond. Let's assume we want a number between 0 and 100, so we calculate 100*0.148452=14~ and you get 14 only in 148 microseconds. Let's see for example you click a button to request a random number, so you click it when the time is 0.148452 you get 14 then you click 1 second later to get the same results BUT it means you have to be 10 microsecond precise between clicks that's impossible for humans. In automatic operations like encryptions it may result in the same number since the code that runs on the computer can run in almost the same interval, but if you add it to video games that is controlled by user input then pseudo-randomness is perfect. Or when you obfuscate randomness with randomness for example you delay the calculations for random microseconds, so it should calculate more things before the next random number is requested. Speaking of that CPU clock cycle is determined by the crystal oscillator that is affected by its temperature and the temperature is pretty much random over time, so the cycle delays itself in a very little amount of ticks. And you can even call it true randomness since the result comes from so many quantum factors that it's almost unpredictable.

To anybody who may misunderstand his message about god:
Einstein made a famous quote about the origin of the universe that goes something like "God does not play dice," referring to his own conviction that the universe is not completely random.
Michael was using the term "God" metaphorically, as a way of playing with Einstein's quote in order to make a point about randomness in the universe.

In simpler words, it's a metaphor. He was not suggesting anything about the existence or non-existence of any metaphysical being.

See, I personally don't believe in randomness. I believe everything that has/will ever happen in the universe was predetermined by something else and there is/was only one possible outcome of the universe. It is impossible for a human to make a decision randomly because previous experiences affect our cognitions, even if it was a really difficult decision, the decision was already made for you by your previous experiences. This therefore suggests that we are not in control of our own actions and in a sense, our lives are being lived for us and we're just along for the ride. As you said in the video, even coin flips are redetermined by the forces which act upon them, which in tern is determined by the strength in your thumb, which is determined by things such as genes and nutrition. You cannot escape the determinism.

I never understood the "observing thing" in quantum physic.
Basically if I understood right, it say that a particle hasn't any state until you observe it. (like the Schroedinger cat). BUT it doesn't make sense.For me it's just that we don't know how to predict the state of a particle, so we are forced to observe it for know this state. It's not that the particle is in both or more state, it's just that we don't know because we can't measure it yet.
It's like saying : My friend sleep sometime, I don't have the sufficient knowledge to predict it. So, until I observe him, he is in both state (awake and sleeping) until I observe him. And when I observe him, he'll go in one state or another and it's because I observe him that he went in one state. x_x

In the end, I just think it's just that we miss a key factor for really knowing how quantum particles react.

There's technically no such thing as random in the universe even at a quantum level. Over a long enough period of time everything will fall into a pattern. Even the decay of atoms and the spin of an electron will eventually map out a recognizable pattern. We're just not looking at things at a long enough time scale to see a pattern yet. Trouble is that the time scales needed to actually find patterns in everything in the universe might only be measured in lengths longer than the entire life of the universe itself. Just because the smallest particles don't obey any laws of nature we place upon larger structures doesn't mean they exist in a true random state. It''s just that we haven't discerned their particular rule book is all. True randomness can't actually exist for their to be any organization at a higher order. Entropy doesn't allow it.

i was thinking about this a while ago, so nice to see a video about it, i was wondering, how a computer could generate "random" outcomes. because, as it is right now, computers need to be programmed to do something. so it could never realy be random.

the other day, i was baking an egg. and when i looked at the bubbles around the egg, i thought to myself, if i were to look at the egg, without knowing what is underneath it, the bubbles would appear to be completely random. although it realy isn't. the location, timing and size of the bubbles, are in fact calculable. if you know all the factors, such as, that there is a heatsource. and if you know what the surface of, both the egg, and the pan look like you should, in theory be able to calculate the behaviour of the bubbles.

maybe, it's the same thing with radiation. or nuclear decay. i was tought that, this is a completely random process. but now i thought, maybe it isn't, maybe it's calculable just like the bubbles around the egg. only we don't know what all the factors are, so it appears to be random.

i thought that it was an interesting thought, and it's nice to see a video about the topic.

I once had pub conversation with a maths student, he insisted that i'd find nothing he'd learned interesting. I pressed and insisted that there must be something he'd found wondrous and perhaps i would too. He then proceeded to explain the system and step-by-step randomisation of a lottery draw machine. He threw numbers and terms around and, apart from stating that he was "probably getting the numbers way off", had me rapt. Having someone run you through the chaotic shifts happening between releasing the balls at one particular second or another, the different ball set configurations and how they change things, even the paddles mixing the balls/ causing the first to bounce at an angle (thereby affecting every other falling numbered ball)... may not sound impressive, but holy hell did he bring the maths alive and figuratively blew my mind.
